ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SKILLS DEVELOPMENT LEVY


    1. Mr John De Payva asked the Minister for Trade and Industry whether he will consider (i) increasing the Skills Development Levy rate to 4% and (ii) revising the salary ceiling for the Levy to $1,500.

     The Minister of State for Trade and Industry (Mr Goh Chee Wee) (for the Minister for Trade and Industry): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government announced in February last year that the salary ceiling for the Skills Development Levy will be raised from $750 to $1,000, but the rate will remain at 1%. The revision will take effect from April this year.

    We also said in the same announcement that the salary ceiling will need to be raised further in the future in order for the annual levy collection to match the annual disbursements of training grants from the Skills Development Fund (SDF). The SDF will continue to play a key role in the skills training and upgrading of our workers. It must therefore be adequately funded. My Ministry will continue to review the levy collection and funding requirements periodically, and make further revisions when necessary.

     Mr John De Payva (Nominated Member): Sir, would the Minister be in a position to tell us how many people in Singapore would be contributing based on the impending salary ceiling of $1,000?

Column: 997



     Mr Goh Chee Wee: With the salary ceiling of $1,000, it will cover about 50% of the workers.

PUBLIC UTILITIES BOARD
(Termination of gas supply to older private housing estates)


    2. Mr Goh Choon Kang asked the Minister for Trade and Industry why the Public Utilities Board has decided to terminate the gas supply to older private housing estates and how many estates are affected.

     Mr Goh Chee Wee (for the Minister for Trade and Industry): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Public Utilities Board (PUB) will be terminating piped gas supply to 40 low-rise estates affecting 15,970 households over the next two to three years.

    Gas pipes in these estates were laid between 22 and 40 years ago. Over the years, house owners have built extensions in their backyards over the run of these gas pipes, thereby rendering maintenance of gas pipes difficult, if not impossible. These gas pipes could be corroded and the risk of gas leak would increase as the pipes get older. The leakage of gas could accumulate in the voids beneath the house extension and accumulate into an explosive mixture. Hence, for safety reasons, these pipes have to be replaced.

    However, the cost of re-laying new pipes is very high and is not economically viable in view of the small number of households which use PUB piped gas in these estates. Although all housing units in the 40 affected estates are served by the PUB gas network, only 46% of them use PUB gas. It would not be justifiable for PUB to expend large sums of public fund when the majority of residents are not using PUB gas but bottled LPG.

    Those households using PUB gas now would not be unduly inconvenienced as they can switch to LPG which is readily available and competitively priced. However, if the affected households wish to continue with PUB gas supply, they could collectively, within each estate, make a capital contribution towards part of the cost of laying the new gas pipes in

Column: 998

order to make the gas mains renewal project financially viable. Additionally, each household would have to bear the cost of laying a new gas service pipe within his premises. It is estimated that each household would have to pay between $2,000 and $17,000 depending on the location and number of households in the estate. The average cost is $4,000 per household.

    To-date, PUB has served notice to seven estates but has yet to terminate supply to any. The Members of Parliament of these seven estates have been informed of the intention and the rationale behind this exercise. Some households have already applied to cut off gas supply following the notification.

    I would like to assure Members that PUB will continue to render all possible assistance to affected households and will carry out the exercise in a manner which will cause least inconvenience to them.

     Mr Goh Choon Kang (Braddell Heights): Sir, what is the total cost of re-laying the gas pipes in all these estates?

     Mr Goh Chee Wee: It depends on the housing estate concerned. The figures I quoted, ie, between $2,000 and $17,000, are the contribution to be made by the households. The cost actually depends on the estate concerned, ie, the condition of the pipes, the pipelines, the layout, etc.

     Mr Goh Choon Kang: Would the Government consider doing this as an upgrading project for the private housing estates?

     Mr Goh Chee Wee: I have already explained the rationale why, from PUB's analysis, it is not economically viable to re-lay the pipes. But if the residents insist that they want the PUB gas supply and they are prepared to bear part of the cost, PUB will oblige.

     Mr Goh Choon Kang: My question is whether the Government is prepared to do this as an upgrading project, just like the Government is upgrading the HDB estates.

     Mr Goh Chee Wee: Even if the residents pay the cost which I have mentioned, they only bear part of the cost of laying the pipes.

Column: 999



     Mr Goh Choon Kang: Compared to the total cost, what is the percentage?

     Mr Goh Chee Wee: As I mentioned, it depends on the estate. In this case, I also want to mention that the residents have an alternative. They can always switch to LPG gas which is available at more or less the same price as PUB gas.

     Mr Goh Choon Kang: Can we work on a similar formula for upgrading of HDB estates?

     Mr Goh Chee Wee: If the Member wishes to put up a proposal as to the percentage of cost that the residents are prepared to bear, I think we are prepared to consider.

     Mr Goh Choon Kang: Can the Minister of State convey this proposal to the Cabinet?

     Mr Goh Chee Wee: As I said, the figures I quoted have been worked out by the PUB and it is part of the total cost of laying the pipes. If the Member feels that the PUB should contribute more, we would be pleased to hear suggestions from the Member.

Column: 999

GENERAL ELECTION


    3. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Prime Minister when the next general election shall be held.

     The Prime Minister (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the next general election shall be held not later than 5th April 1997.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Was there any substance in the widespread rumour that the general election was scheduled to be held on 17th December last year and was cancelled?

     Mr Speaker: Mr Chiam, your question is out of order. No reference is to be made to any rumour.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Was the Prime Minister aware that even syndicated gamblers could pinpoint that the election date was 17th December last year?

     The Prime Minister: The Prime Minister was not aware.

Column: 1000



     Mr Chiam See Tong: Was there any possible leak in the Prime Minister's Office which generated such a lot of betting for that particular date for election to be held?

     The Prime Minister: There could be no possibility of a leak because I had not yet decided on when the election would be held.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Was the Prime Minister aware that teachers were told not to go on overseas holiday and police officers were also told not to take leave last December?

     The Prime Minister: I was not aware.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Is the Prime Minister aware that whenever an election seems to be coming, there would be widespread betting on that date?

     The Prime Minister: That I am aware.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: In view of trying to curb such gambling which might bring down the seriousness of these elections, would the Prime Minister be willing to fix elections at regular fixed dates, say, August or December of every fourth year after the last general election?

     The Prime Minister: The answer is no. Even if we fix a particular date, I think that gambling would also be prevalent, perhaps on the result of the election. You cannot eradicate gambling just by simply fixing a date for the election.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: If the Prime minister is not willing to have fixed dates for general elections, would the Prime Minister give us the reasons for that?

     The Prime Minister: The Prime Minister follows what is written in the Constitution religiously.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: But regular practice has it that general elections seem to be held every four years rather than three years. Why not start a precedent by having elections every four years so that all those who wish to take part will not be inconvenienced and I think it would be fairer to everybody? In fact, it would be in line with the Prime Minister's declaration

Column: 1001

that he wants to have openness. Let us have openness in regard to the general election.

     The Prime Minister: The present practice has worked very well and there is no compelling reason whatsoever to change the practice. Mr Chiam suggested that we should change the practice in order to eradicate illegal gambling. I do not see that as a compelling reason for us to change the current practice of having an election within a certain date as stipulated in the Constitution. May I suggest that Mr Chiam should always be ready for election which may be called at any time before the due date.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: I have always been ready. Would it not be better for everybody to have regular dates for general elections to be held? What is there for the Government to fear since the Government has always said that it has got a good record?

     The Prime Minister: The Government has got nothing to fear. When an election is due, due notice will be given to everybody concerned and the election will be fought on the usual practice.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Is the Prime Minister's tactic always to ambush the Opposition?

     The Prime Minister: If the Opposition falls into an ambush, that is the fault of the Opposition.

Column: 1001

SPEED LIMIT
(Increase from 50 km/h to 70 km/h)


    4. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether he will increase the speed limit from 50 km/h to 70 km/h on certain roads where speed-detection cameras are installed.

SPEED-DETECTION CAMERAS ALONG EXPRESSWAYS

(Hazard to motorists)


    5. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether the speed-detection cameras installed along

Column: 1002

expressways will pose a hazard to motorists as some drivers suddenly reduce speed after seeing the camera box.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I take Questions Nos. 4 and 5 together as they are related?

     Mr Speaker: All right.

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, speed detection cameras are a means to curb and deter speeding. Their mere presence does not render a road suitable for its speed limit to be raised. On the contrary, it is at locations where vehicles frequently speed and where accidents are more likely to occur as a result of speeding (for example, Holland Road) that speed detection cameras are installed.

    Recently, separate from the question of speed detection cameras, there have been suggestions in the press that existing speed limits be raised. Others, however, have argued that the present speed limits are appropriate and should remain.

    The departments concerned, ie, Traffic Police, PWD and ROV, take great care in recommending speed limits for our roads. The maximum speed we can allow on a particular road would depend on all the factors that affect traffic safety, ie, the physical nature of the road itself such as its width and existence of bends, presence of merging lanes, slip roads and centre dividers, the general traffic volume of different classes of road users and vehicles and also, in general, the behaviour of road users including the level of road courtesy.

    In the past, Singapore had only two speed limits - 50 km per hour for most roads and 70 km per hour for the larger and wider roads. 80 km per hour was introduced when expressways were constructed. At some portions of expressways, the speed limit is lower (70 km per hour) for safety reasons, eg, in the Central Expressway tunnel. These speed limits are reviewed periodically. Based on the above factors, setting appropriate speed limits is a matter of judgment. The

Column: 1003

professionals have, all things considered, advised retaining the present speed limits. We should abide by their judgment.

    While some motorists, eg, those who drive higher capacity cars, may feel safe driving at speeds above the present speed limits, we must not forget that there are many other road users who drive smaller cars or who are relatively inexperienced. At higher speeds, they would have less margin for avoiding accidents. The Commander of Traffic Police informs me that high speed compounds the effect of other causes of accidents, such as skidding, failure to have proper control of vehicle, overtaking dangerously, changing lanes without consideration for other road users and tail-gating. At high speed, a driver is less able to have complete control of his vehicle; he also has less time to react to changing traffic conditions and potentially hazardous situations. An accident which occurs at high speed causes greater damage and injury. Death is also more likely in high speed accidents.

    Studies in the United States in 1990 show that raising speed limits have led to increased road casualties. Their figures show that when some 38 states raised their speed limits from 55 miles per hour to 65 miles per hour, deaths rocketed by 34% compared with the previous four-year period. In eight states where the limits were retained, the increase was just 8%.

    I am concerned with what our statistics show. Since 1992, there has been an increasing trend in fatal cases in speed related accidents. In 1992, there were 93 cases. This rose to 96 cases in 1993 and 118 cases in 1994. Do we want the number to go higher? The answer must surely be no.

    Let us not forget that we live in a largely urban environment. Our roads and expressways are not as long as the highways of other countries. Our expressways have slip roads at relatively short intervals. It is not advisable to have too many different speed limits on different stretches as this will lead to confusion. The PWD who are the experts

Column: 1004

in road engineering have also advised that the speed limit of 80 km per hour is an appropriate speed limit for our expressways. In the interest of traffic safety, we should not increase our speed limits.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang has asked whether the speed detection cameras installed along the expressways would pose a hazard to motorists, as some motorists might suddenly reduce speed after seeing the camera box. Such a situation should not occur if motorists travel within the speed limit of the road at all times. However, I am not saying that the problem highlighted by Mr Low could not happen. Nevertheless, I hope that he is not suggesting that we do away with the speed camera on this account. Speed cameras, in the long run, would save more lives by deterring speeding on our roads and expressways.

    It is not Traffic Police's intention to catch the motorists by surprise. Traffic Police have provided full details of the locations of these cameras. In addition, there are prominent signs to give sufficient advance warning to motorists on the road. Over time, as motorists get used to the idea of the speed camera and, more importantly, comply with the speed limits on our roads, even in locations without cameras, the problem highlighted by Mr Low should not occur.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, since the Parliamentary Secretary cannot deny the fact that there is a possibility of such a hazard, would he suggest any measure to reduce the hazard, if possible?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: I think the so-called hazard that Mr Low has mentioned arises essentially from the newness of the scheme and the fact that drivers are not keeping to the speed limits. Therefore, when they are approaching the camera, they slow down. If this exercise has its desired impact of reminding Singaporeans that there are speed limits, it is for their benefit as well as for the benefit of public safety to keep to the speed limits, when this gets to the ground over time, this so-called hazard that Mr Low mentioned will not be present any more.

Column: 1005



     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, if the motorists are familiar with the location of the cameras, they reduce the speed at that stretch of the road, but after that they increase their speed again. How do you achieve the purpose of installing the speed detection cameras? You have to install cameras for the whole stretch.

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: It would seem that Mr Low is actually suggesting the installation of more cameras.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Are you going to do that?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: This is a pilot project. Six cameras have been installed all over the island. The Traffic Police says that after another five months, they would review. Should the pilot project prove successful, yes, indeed more cameras will be installed. Whilst that will deter speeding in most areas of Singapore, I think the ultimate message must really be that Traffic Police is not out to catch motorists. And that is why great pains have been taken, both in the press and also on location on the ground, to let motorists know where the cameras are. The exercise is to remind Singaporeans that speeding is something that all of us should not do and the cameras reinforce this message.

     Dr Kanwaljit Soin (Nominated Member): Sir, would the Parliamentary Secretary consider having speed regulating strips at the stretches where there are cameras so that the cars will slow down?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, I am not sure whether motorists will really like that because they will talk about possible damage to their vehicles' tyres. And also that will be an overkill because once you have the speed detection cameras, they know that the message is for them to stop speeding. I think that will suffice. We do not want to impose too many different types of mechanisms.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that the general feedback is that 50 km per hour is unfair?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Unfair to whom?

Column: 1006



     Mr Chiam See Tong: It is too low for the motorists.

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: I think we must bear in mind that Singapore is an urban setting where our roads are used not just by motorists who have high capacity cars like Volvos and Mercedeses but also motorists who drive smaller capacity cars. Also the types of drivers in Singapore are of such a wide diversity. Some are more experienced, perhaps like Mr Chiam, and others are less experienced. All things considered, it is better to heed the professional advice of the Committee and keep the speed limits as they are.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that along Holland Road, whenever motorists approach the speed detection camera, they will slow down? As soon as they pass this camera, they will pick up speed again, defeating the purpose of this camera.

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: We cannot control, as it were, the specific behaviour of the road users. But I think we must keep in mind the larger objective of these speed detection cameras which is to reinforce the message that speeding is an offence and that they are for the benefit of motorists themselves. As the press reports have said, now less people in fact speed along that stretch of road. I think that is evidence that the message is filtering down to the ground.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar GRC): Sir, I would like to ask the Parliamentary Secretary whether the pedestrian's well-being is a primary factor.

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, as I said just now, there is a wide diversity of people using the roads, including not only motorists but pedestrians, cyclists and even drivers of lorries and trucks. Given this situation in Singapore, let us be conservative. Some may argue that 50 km per hour is low. But I think we should be conservative, play safe and make sure that the central message of public safety for all concerned gets through. That is important.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, the Parliamentary Secretary mentioned about the

Column: 1007

diversity of people using the roads. Pedestrians are supposed to use the pedestrian crossings or overhead bridges. As for lorries, they have their own speed limits, have they not? Why is it that you are blanketing the speed limit to 50 km per hour?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, we are not blanketing the speed limit to 50 km per hour.     12. Dr Kanwaljit Soin asked the Minister for Trade and Industry what are the main recommendations of the task force set up in early 1994 (with the Singapore Tourist Promotion Board and other agencies) to look into raising standards in Singapore shops.

It is only fair that all owners of OPCs or WECs, regardless of their engine capacities, be subject to similar usage restraint and be given similar tax concession.
